doc_name: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks
pdf_source: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

metadata.document_name: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks
metadata.source_pdf: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
* Deemed abandonment under Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act: Whether notice of opposition was validly served on the applicant?
* Service of notice under Section 21(2): Was the appellant's agent, M/s Manmohan Singh and Associates, properly served with notice of opposition by speed post?
* Proof of service: Can the Registry rely solely on a statement that notice was sent by speed post without providing any document to confirm receipt or delivery?
* Timeliness of response under Section 21(2): Did the applicant fail to file a counter-statement within two months from receipt of notice, as required by law?

* Abandonment of application: Can an application be deemed abandoned if the applicant failed to respond within the prescribed timeframe without proving that they had no intention to proceed with the application?
These legal issues relate to the interpretation and application of Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Summary of the Legal Case**

**Background:**

The present appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021) was filed by Purushottam Singhal, Proprietor of MS Prime Cable Industries (Appellant), against the Registrar of Trade Marks and Another (Respondents).

**Facts:**

*   On November 20, 1997, the Appellant submitted an application seeking registration of the trademark "PRIME CAB" in Class 9 of the NICE classification with the Registrar of Trade Marks.
*   The first Examination Report (FER) was issued on June 29, 2001, and the Appellant replied on September 5, 2001.
*   Opposition to the registration of "PRIME CAB" was filed by Respondent 2 on July 14, 2006.
*   According to the Appellant's case, neither the Appellant nor its authorized agents were served with notice of the opposition.

**Legal Issues:**

The central legal issue in this case is whether the Appellant can be deemed to have abandoned their application for registration of "PRIME CAB" because they failed to respond to the notice of opposition within the stipulated timeframe of 2 months from receipt of the notice.

**Arguments by Parties:**

*   The Appellant (through counsel, Mr. Akash Swami) argued that they were never served with notice of the opposition, contrary to Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act, requiring the registrar to serve a copy of the notice on the applicant.
*   Respondent 1 (the Registry of Trade Marks) submitted that notice of the opposition was sent by speed post to the Appellant's agent, M/s Manmohan Singh & Associates.

**Court Findings:**

The Court noted that:

*   No documentary evidence was presented by Respondents to prove the despatch or delivery of the notice of opposition either to the agent or to the Appellant.
*   The testimony provided by counsel for Respondent 1 (Ms. Mehra) that the notice of opposition was sent via speed post on March 18th, 2019, without a postal receipt.

**Decision:**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi held that: since there is no sufficient evidence proving service, the Appellant should not be deemed to have abandoned the application for registration. Therefore, the appeal is allowed, and the impugned order was set aside by the Registrar who shall now consider the application as if it were fresh.

The Court also noted that: Respondent 2, whose opposition this is, must proceed with their case in accordance with law if the applicant proceeds to file a new response after service of notice.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 1 of 8  
 
   
$~3 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021 
PURUSHOTTAM SINGHAL PROPRIETOR MS. PRIME 
CABLE INDUSTRIES  
 
 
            ..... Appellant 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. Akash Swami, Adv. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS & ANR.        ..... Respondents 
Through: 
Ms. Shreya V. Mehra for Mr. 
Kirtiman Singh, Adv. for R-1 
Mr. Bikash Ghorai, Ms Anju Agrawal and Mr. 
Deepak Panwar, Advs. for R-2 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C. HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
 
1. 
This appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 assails 
order dated 14
JUDGMENT (O R A L) 
% 
 
 
 
 
20.03.2023 
 
 
th June 2019, passed on behalf of the Registrar of Trade 
Marks, whereby Application No. 779092, filed by the appellant seeking 
registration of the trade mark PRIME CAB has been rejected as having 
been deemed to have been abandoned by the appellant, invoking, for the 
purpose, Section 21(2)1
 
 of the Trade Marks Act. 
                                          
1 21.  
Opposition to registration. –  
(1)  
Any person may, within four months from the date of the advertisement or re-advertisement of 
an application for registration, give notice in writing in the prescribed manner and on payment of such 
fee as may be prescribed, to the Registrar, of opposition to the registration. 
(2)  
The Registrar shall serve a copy of the notice on the applicant for registration and, within two 
months from the receipt by the applicant of such copy of the notice of opposition, the applicant shall 
send to the Registrar in the prescribed manner a counter statement of the grounds on which he relies for 
his application, and if he does not do so he shall be deemed to have abandoned his application. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 2 of 8  
 
   
2. 
The application seeking registration of the mark PRIME CAB in 
Class 9 of the NICE classification was submitted by the appellant on 20th 
November 1997 in the office of the Registrar. First Examination Report 
(FER) was issued on or on behalf of the Registrar on 29th June 2001, to 
which the appellant filed his reply on 5th
 
 September 2001. 
3. 
Various other proceedings took place with respect to the said 
application, including proceedings which travelled to this Court, which 
are not of particular relevance to the dispute at hand. 
 
4. 
For the purpose of the present dispute, suffice it to state that an 
opposition was filed by Respondent 2, to the application of the appellant, 
on 14th
 
 July 2006. 
5. 
The appellant’s case is that neither was the appellant, nor was any 
of its authorised agents, ever served with notice of the opposition filed by 
Respondent 2, as required by Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act.  
 
6. 
Ms. Shreya Mehra, learned Counsel who appears for Respondent 1 
(the Registry of Trade Marks) submits that notice of the opposition filed 
by Respondent 2 was sent to M/s Manmohan Singh and Associates, the 
agent of the appellant, by speed post on 18th
 
 March 2019. Mr. Akash 
Swami, learned Counsel for the appellant submits, on instructions, that 
his client never received any such speed post.  
7. 
Apart from making a statement to the effect that the notice was 
sent by speed post, Ms. Mehra is unable to provide any document 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 3 of 8  
 
   
containing any postal receipt of the notice of opposition having been sent 
by speed post or of the speed post having been delivered to any addressee 
mentioned therein. All that this Court has, therefore, is a bald assertion, 
contained in a note handed over by Ms. Mehra to the effect that the 
notice of opposition was sent to the agent of the appellant by speed post 
on 18th
 
 March 2019.  Ms Mehra offers to say so on affidavit; but, in the 
absence of any proof of the document having in fact been despatched to 
the appellant by speed post, I cannot, quite obviously, accept the said 
statement, even if stated on affidavit.  Ms Mehra is candid in admitting 
that her client has no documentary material evidencing proof of despatch, 
to the appellant, of the notice of hearing of the opposition, at any point of 
time. 
8. 
Mr. Ghorai, who appears on behalf of the Respondent 2, submits 
that, in fact, there was an earlier service of the notice of opposition on the 
appellant vide letter dated 22nd
 
 October 2008. He has filed a reply to the 
present petition, placing a copy of the said letter on record.  
9. 
However, a perusal of the letter dated 22nd October 2008 reveals 
that, while it is addressed to the appellant as well as its agent, the copy 
has been forwarded only to M/s R K Diwan and Co., as is manifest from 
the tick mark alongside the name of M/s R K Diwan and Co. There is 
nothing to indicate that the said notice dated 22nd
 
 October 2008 was ever 
served on the appellant or on any of its authorised agents, or even 
despatched to any of them. 
10. 
At this juncture, Mr. Ghorai again intercedes to draw my attention 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 4 of 8  
 
   
to a letter dated 30th
 
“We submit that the Notice of Opposition filed by us on July 14, 2006, 
was served on the Applicants’ Attorneys under the cover of your letter 
No. TOP/3224 dated 22nd October 2008.” 
 
 March 2013, addressed by M/s R K Diwan and 
Company to the Registrar of Trade Marks, para 1 of which reads thus: 
11. 
I fail to understand as to how the authorised agent of Respondent 2 
could arrogate to itself the authority to certify service of notice of 
opposition on the appellant. To reiterate, there is no document to show 
that the notice dated 22nd
 
 October 2008 was ever served on the appellant 
or on its authorised agent. 
12. 
Indeed, if, in fact, notice of the opposition had been served on the 
appellant or its authorised agent on 22nd October 2008, there is no 
reasonable expression as to why notice of the opposition was again sent 
to the appellant on 18th March 2019. The fact that the Registry deemed it 
appropriate to issue notice of the opposition to the appellant on 18th 
March 2019 also indicates, prima facie, that there was no prior valid 
service of the notice of opposition on the appellant. I have, in fact, 
queried of Ms. Mehra, as to whether there was any prior service of notice 
on the opposition filed by Respondent 2 on the appellant prior to 18th
 
 
March 2019. She frankly submits that she is unaware of any such service. 
13. 
The right to seek registration of a trademark is a valid and valuable 
right which vests in an applicant by the Trade Marks Act. Though there 
is no law which mandates registration of a trade mark, a mark, once 
registered, becomes entitled to valuable privileges under the Act, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 5 of 8  
 
   
including, most importantly, a right to combat infringement, conferred by 
Section 29.  
 
14. 
Once an applicant applies for registration of a trademark, there is 
no reason why the applicant should abandon the application. It is well-
settled, in law, that abandonment is necessarily a voluntary act, and 
cannot be presumed, save and except in the manner in which the law 
entitles such a presumption to be drawn. Insofar as the Trade Marks Act 
is concerned, no doubt, Section 21(2) deems an applicant, who has 
applied for registration of a trade mark, to have abandoned the 
application, if he fails to send, to the Registrar, a counterstatement in 
response to the notice of opposition, by any opponent opposing the 
application, within two months from the date of receipt, by him, of such 
notice of opposition. In view of the severe consequence of the inaction 
envisaged by Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act, the provision has to 
be strictly construed. There must, therefore, be positive evidence of (i) 
service of notice on the applicant, seeking registration of a trade mark, of 
the copy of the notice of opposition and (ii) failure, by the applicant, to 
send a counterstatement, in response to the opposition, within two 
months therefrom. 
 
15. 
Rule 14 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 deals with service of 
documents, and sub-rules (1) to (3) thereof read thus: 
“14. 
Service of documents. –  
 
(1) 
All applications, notices, statements, papers having 
representations affixed thereto, or other documents authorised 
or required by the Act or the rules made thereunder, served, 
left or sent, at or to the Trade Marks Registry or with or to the 
Registrar or any other person may be delivered by hand or sent 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 6 of 8  
 
   
through the post by a prepaid letter or may be submitted 
electronically in the manner as laid down by the Registry. 
 
(2) 
An application or any document so sent shall be 
deemed to have been made, served, left or sent at the time 
when the letter containing the same would be delivered in the 
ordinary course of post. 
 
(3) 
In proving such sending, it shall be sufficient to prove 
that the letter was properly addressed and put into the post.” 
 
16. 
Shorn of superfluities, Rule 14(1) envisages delivery, of all 
applications, notices, statements, papers or other documents, “by hand or 
sent through the post by a pre-paid letter” or electronically in the manner 
laid down by the Registrar. 
 
17. 
In the present case, though the appellant was situated in Delhi, 
there is no proof of any effort having been made to serve the notice of 
opposition dated 14th
 
 July 2006, filed by Respondent 2 on the appellant 
by hand. Nor does Ms. Mehra so assert. 
18. 
Nor is it Ms. Mehra’s case that there was any electronic service of 
the notice of opposition on the appellant. 
 
19. 
Service through post, under Rule 14(1), has to be by a pre-paid 
letter. I have already noted that, save and except for an averment 
contained in the note that Ms. Mehra has handed over across the Bar 
today, there is no proof of any postal service of the notice of the 
opposition dated 14th
 
 July 2006 filed by Respondent 2 having been 
effected on the appellant. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 7 of 8  
 
   
20. 
Mr. Ghorai also places reliance on Rule 17(3)2
 
 of the Trade Marks 
Rules. I am completely baffled as to how the said rule can be at of any 
application whatsoever in the present case. On its plain reading, Rule 
17(3) applies only where no address for service in India is given as 
required by Section 17(1). The address for service of the appellant, as 
given in the plaintiff’s application, was not only in India but was in 
Delhi. There was, therefore, no legitimate reason as to why, in fact, 
notice of the opposition was not served on the appellant by hand, which 
was the first method of service envisaged by Rule 14(1) of the Trade 
Marks Rules. 
21. 
In the present case, there being no proof of any service of the 
notice of opposition of dated 14th
 
 July 2006 of Respondent 2 having been 
effected on the appellant in the manner envisaged by the Trade Marks 
Rules, the invocation, by the impugned order of Section 21(2) of the 
Trade Marks Act must be held to be misguided. 
22. 
I am informed that the notice of opposition dated 14th
                                          
2 17.  
Address for service. –  
(1)  
Every applicant or opponent or any person concerned in any proceeding under the Act or rules 
shall furnish to the Registrar an address for service in India comprising of a postal address in India and a 
valid e-mail address and such address shall be treated as the address for service of such applicant or 
opponent or person: 
Provided that a trade mark agent shall also be required to furnish a mobile number registered 
in India. 
(2)  
Any written communication addressed to a person as aforesaid at an address for service in 
India given by him shall be deemed to be properly addressed. 
(3)  
Unless an address for service in India as required in sub-rule (1) is given, the Registrar shall 
be under no obligation to send any notice that may be required by the Act or the rules and no subsequent 
order or decision in the proceedings shall be called in question on the ground of any lack or non-service 
of notice. 
 
 July 2006 is 
available on the website of the Registrar of Trade Marks. Mr. Swami, 
learned Counsel for the appellant undertakes on behalf of his client to file 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 8 of 8  
 
   
his counterstatement to the notice of opposition within two weeks. It is 
made clear that the appellant should do so within the said time failing 
which the right to file counterstatement would stand closed. 
 
23. 
The Registrar may thereafter proceed with the application in 
accordance with law. 
 
24. 
This appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to costs. 
 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J 
 
MARCH 20, 2023 
 
ar 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the provided document section from the PDF file "39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf":

**Case Summary:**

This case involves an appeal by Purushottam Singhal, proprietor of MS. Prime Cable Industries (the Appellant), against the rejection of a trade mark registration application for "PRIME CAB" (Registration No. 779092).

**Facts and Proceedings:**

1. The Appellant filed a trade mark application on November 20th, 1997.
2. Respondent 2 (one of the parties opposing the application) filed an opposition on July 14th, 2006.
3. The Registry of Trade Marks allegedly served the Appellant's agent with notice of the opposition via speed post on March 18th, 2019.

**Contentions:**

1. The Appellant claims that they never received notice of the opposition, as required by Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act.
2. Respondent 1 (the Registry of Trade Marks) argues that the notice was sent to the Appellant's agent via speed post on March 18th, 2019.

**Parties Involved:**

1. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries (Appellant)
2. Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr. (Respondents)

**Dates and Amounts:**

1. November 20th, 1997 (date of application filing)
2. July 14th, 2006 (date of opposition filing by Respondent 2)
3. March 18th, 2019 (alleged date of notice sent to Appellant's agent)

This summary is based on the provided document section from the PDF file "39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf".

**Case Details**

* Case title: Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries vs Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023:DHC:1993
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) No.: 13/2021

**Proceedings**

* Appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 has been filed against an order dated June 14, 2019.
* The appeal challenges the rejection of trade mark Application No. 779092 for registration.

**Parties**

* Appellant: Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries
* Respondent: Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr

**Arguments/ Decisions**

* The matter is before Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar.
* Date of Order: March 20, 2023.

Source: Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf (note: the PDF link is not accessible).

**Background**

* The appellant's (Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries) application for trade mark registration of "PRIME CAB" was submitted on November 20, 1997.
* First Examination Report (FER) was issued on June 29, 2001, and a reply was filed by the appellant.

**Dispute over Service**

* Respondent 1 submits that notice of the opposition was sent to the appellant's agent by speed post on March 18, 2019.
* The appellant denies receiving the notice and contests its delivery.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
This is a court decision from the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (2023:DHC:1993), case number C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021. The parties involved are:

**Appellant:** Purushottam Singhal, Proprietor MS Prime Cable Industries
**Respondents:** Registrar of Trade Marks and Anr.

**Background and Facts:**

The Respondent filed an opposition to the Appellant's trademark application in 2006. However, there is a dispute over whether the notice of opposition was properly served on the Appellant. The Respondent claimed that the notice was sent by speed post on March 18, 2019, but no documentary evidence was provided.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

The Court heard arguments from both parties and examined the documents produced:

* The Respondent's counsel, Mr. Ghorai, submitted that an earlier service of notice was made on October 22, 2008.
* However, this claim was disputed as there is no indication that the notice was served on the Appellant or its authorized agents.
* The Court noted that if a valid service was made in 2008, it is unclear why another notice was sent to the Appellant in 2019.

**Decision:**

The Court concluded that without concrete evidence of prior service, they cannot assume that the Respondent's claim is true. Therefore, they cannot proceed with further proceedings based on this assumption. The case number and source link are the same as provided.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF:

**Case Details**

Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021 

**Proceedings**

Ms Mehra, on behalf of the Respondents, submits that a notice of opposition was sent to the Appellant's agent by speed post on March 18, 2019. However, there is no proof of despatch or delivery. Ms Mehra admits that her client has no documentary material evidencing proof of service.

**Submissions by Mr. Ghorai**

Mr. Ghorai argues that an earlier notice of opposition was served on the Appellant vide letter dated October 22, 2008. He places a copy of the letter on record. However, upon examination, it is revealed that the copy was forwarded to M/s R K Diwan and Co., but there is no indication that the notice was served on the Appellant or its authorized agents.

**No Documentary Evidence**

The Court notes that there is no proof of service or despatch of either the notice of opposition or the hearing notice, rendering Ms Mehra's assertion unfounded.

 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 3 of 8  
 
   
containing any postal receipt of the notice of opposition having been sent 
by speed post or of the speed post having been delivered to any addressee 
mentioned therein. All that this Court has, therefore, is a bald assertion, 
contained in a note handed over by Ms. Mehra to the effect that the 
notice of opposition was sent to the agent of the appellant by speed post 
on 18th
 
 March 2019.  Ms Mehra offers to say so on affidavit; but, in the 
absence of any proof of the document having in fact been despatched to 
the appellant by speed post, I cannot, quite obviously, accept the said 
statement, even if stated on affidavit.  Ms Mehra is candid in admitting 
that her client has no documentary material evidencing proof of despatch, 
to the appellant, of the notice of hearing of the opposition, at any point of

8. 
Mr. Ghorai, who appears on behalf of the Respondent 2, submits 
that, in fact, there was an earlier service of the notice of opposition on the 
appellant vide letter dated 22nd
 
 October 2008. He has filed a reply to the

that, while it is addressed to the appellant as well as its agent, the copy 
has been forwarded only to M/s R K Diwan and Co., as is manifest from 
the tick mark alongside the name of M/s R K Diwan and Co. There is 
nothing to indicate that the said notice dated 22nd
 
 October 2008 was ever 
served on the appellant or on any of its authorised agents, or even 
despatched to any of them. 
10. 
At this juncture, Mr. Ghorai again intercedes to draw my attention 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 from the provided PDF (MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks):

**Court Case:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021
**Judge's Ruling:**

The judge notes that the respondent, M/s R K Diwan and Company, submitted a letter dated March 2013 to the Registrar of Trade Marks stating that notice of opposition was served on the appellant (Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries) under the cover of a letter No. TOP/3224 dated 22nd October 2008.

**Appellant's Argument:**

The appellant argues that this service is invalid as there is no document to show that the notice was served on them or their authorized agent. The judge points out that if the notice was indeed served, it is unclear why an additional notice was sent to the appellant on 18th March 2019.

**Judge's Observation:**

The judge notes that there is no evidence of prior service of the notice of opposition on the appellant and observes that the right to seek registration of a trademark is a valuable right under the Trade Marks Act.

PDF Source: MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks (2023:DHC:1993)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 4 of 8  
 
   
to a letter dated 30th
 
“We submit that the Notice of Opposition filed by us on July 14, 2006, 
was served on the Applicants’ Attorneys under the cover of your letter 
No. TOP/3224 dated 22nd October 2008.” 
 
 March 2013, addressed by M/s R K Diwan and 
Company to the Registrar of Trade Marks, para 1 of which reads thus: 
11. 
I fail to understand as to how the authorised agent of Respondent 2 
could arrogate to itself the authority to certify service of notice of 
opposition on the appellant. To reiterate, there is no document to show 
that the notice dated 22nd
 
 October 2008 was ever served on the appellant 
or on its authorised agent. 
12. 
Indeed, if, in fact, notice of the opposition had been served on the 
appellant or its authorised agent on 22nd October 2008, there is no 
reasonable expression as to why notice of the opposition was again sent 
to the appellant on 18th March 2019. The fact that the Registry deemed it 
appropriate to issue notice of the opposition to the appellant on 18th 
March 2019 also indicates, prima facie, that there was no prior valid 
service of the notice of opposition on the appellant. I have, in fact, 
queried of Ms. Mehra, as to whether there was any prior service of notice 
on the opposition filed by Respondent 2 on the appellant prior to 18th
 
 
March 2019. She frankly submits that she is unaware of any such service. 
13. 
The right to seek registration of a trademark is a valid and valuable 
right which vests in an applicant by the Trade Marks Act. Though there 
is no law which mandates registration of a trade mark, a mark, once 
registered, becomes entitled to valuable privileges under the Act, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Case:** Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023:DHC:1993

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Case Type:** Civil Appeal (COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021

**Parties:**

* Appellant: Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries
* Respondents:
	+ Registrar of Trade Marks
	+ Ms. Mehra (an opponent)

**Background:**
The appellant had applied for trademark registration, which was opposed by the respondent Ms. Mehra. The Registry deemed the application abandoned under Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act for failure to file a counterstatement.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

* **Abandonment**: The court held that abandonment is a voluntary act and cannot be presumed unless proved in accordance with law.
* **Proof of service**: To deem an applicant as having abandoned their application, there must be positive evidence of (i) serving the notice of opposition and (ii) failing to respond within 2 months.
* **Service of documents**: Rule 14 of the Trade Marks Rules requires service by hand or through a prepaid letter with proof that the letter was properly addressed and posted.

**Decisions:**

* The court found that there was no proof of service of the notice of opposition on the appellant by hand, nor any electronic service.
* No proof of postal service existed, except for an unverified averment made orally in court.
* Therefore, the Registry's decision to deem the application abandoned under Section 21(2) was quashed.

**Source:** [39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://example.com/Purushottam\_Singhal\_Proprietor
tree_structure.pdf_source: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Since you didn't provide page 5 of the PDF document, I'll assume that the content provided is just a small snippet and will summarize the key points from it.

**Case:** Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks [2023:DHC:1993]

**Key Points:**

1. An applicant's right to combat infringement, as conferred by Section 29, is an important consideration.
2. Abandonment of a trademark application must be a voluntary act and cannot be presumed unless there is positive evidence (service of notice on the applicant and failure to respond).
3. Rule 14 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 deals with service of documents.

**Source:** PDF document titled "39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks"
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 5 of 8  
 
   
including, most importantly, a right to combat infringement, conferred by 
Section 29.  
 
14. 
Once an applicant applies for registration of a trademark, there is 
no reason why the applicant should abandon the application. It is well-
settled, in law, that abandonment is necessarily a voluntary act, and 
cannot be presumed, save and except in the manner in which the law 
entitles such a presumption to be drawn. Insofar as the Trade Marks Act 
is concerned, no doubt, Section 21(2) deems an applicant, who has 
applied for registration of a trade mark, to have abandoned the 
application, if he fails to send, to the Registrar, a counterstatement in 
response to the notice of opposition, by any opponent opposing the 
application, within two months from the date of receipt, by him, of such 
notice of opposition. In view of the severe consequence of the inaction 
envisaged by Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act, the provision has to 
be strictly construed. There must, therefore, be positive evidence of (i) 
service of notice on the applicant, seeking registration of a trade mark, of 
the copy of the notice of opposition and (ii) failure, by the applicant, to 
send a counterstatement, in response to the opposition, within two 
months therefrom. 
 
15. 
Rule 14 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 deals with service of 
documents, and sub-rules (1) to (3) thereof read thus: 
“14. 
Service of documents. –  
 
(1) 
All applications, notices, statements, papers having 
representations affixed thereto, or other documents authorised 
or required by the Act or the rules made thereunder, served, 
left or sent, at or to the Trade Marks Registry or with or to the 
Registrar or any other person may be delivered by hand or sent 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the provided PDF (39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf):

**Case Details**

* Case Number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023:DHC:1993

**Rule 14(1) Interpretation**

The court interprets Rule 14(1), which states that applications, notices, and documents can be delivered "by hand or sent through the post by a pre-paid letter" or electronically.

**Service of Notice of Opposition**

In this case, there is no proof that the notice of opposition was served on the appellant (Respondent 2) by hand. Nor was it submitted electronically. Moreover, the service through post is also not proven as there is no record of a prepaid letter being sent to the appellant.

**Relevant Rules and Court Rulings**

The court refers to Rule 14(1) and its provisions regarding the modes of delivery of applications, notices, statements, papers or other documents.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 6 of 8  
 
   
through the post by a prepaid letter or may be submitted 
electronically in the manner as laid down by the Registry. 
 
(2) 
An application or any document so sent shall be 
deemed to have been made, served, left or sent at the time 
when the letter containing the same would be delivered in the 
ordinary course of post. 
 
(3) 
In proving such sending, it shall be sufficient to prove 
that the letter was properly addressed and put into the post.” 
 
16. 
Shorn of superfluities, Rule 14(1) envisages delivery, of all 
applications, notices, statements, papers or other documents, “by hand or 
sent through the post by a pre-paid letter” or electronically in the manner 
laid down by the Registrar. 
 
17. 
In the present case, though the appellant was situated in Delhi, 
there is no proof of any effort having been made to serve the notice of 
opposition dated 14th
 
 July 2006, filed by Respondent 2 on the appellant 
by hand. Nor does Ms. Mehra so assert. 
18. 
Nor is it Ms. Mehra’s case that there was any electronic service of 
the notice of opposition on the appellant. 
 
19. 
Service through post, under Rule 14(1), has to be by a pre-paid 
letter. I have already noted that, save and except for an averment 
contained in the note that Ms. Mehra has handed over across the Bar 
today, there is no proof of any postal service of the notice of the 
opposition dated 14th
 
 July 2006 filed by Respondent 2 having been 
effected on the appellant. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:21.03.2023
12:50:28
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Source:** Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks (2023:DHC:1993), Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021, High Court of Delhi

**Background:** The appellant, Purushottam Singhal, proprietor of MS. Prime Cable Industries, filed an application under the Trade Marks Act for registration of a trade mark. The registrar received an opposition from Respondent 2, and notice of the opposition was supposedly served on the appellant.

**Court Decision:**

The single judge bench of C. Hari Shankar, J., reversed a previous order made by the Registrar of Trade Marks. The court ruled that:

*   **Notice of Opposition not served**: There is no proof of service of the notice of opposition dated July 14, 2006.
*   **Invoking Section 21(2) misguided**: As there was no proper service of notice, invoking Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act was incorrect.
*   **Appellant allowed to file counter-statement**: The court directed the appellant to file a counter-statement within two weeks. Failing which, their right to do so will stand closed.

**Order:** This appeal is allowed with no orders as to costs.

The decision was pronounced on March 20, 2023.

PDF source: Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the PDF:

**Case:** PURUSHOTTAM SINGHAL PROPRIETOR MS. PRIME CABLE INDUSTRIES v. REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS & ANR.

**Page 7 Summary:**

The court discusses Rule 17(3) of the Trade Marks Rules, which states that if an address for service in India is not given, the Registrar has no obligation to send notice and subsequent orders or decisions cannot be questioned due to lack of notice. However, in this case, the appellant's address was in Delhi, so there was a legitimate reason for serving notice via hand.

The court notes that there is no proof of service of the notice of opposition dated July 14, 2006, on the appellant in accordance with the Trade Marks Rules. Therefore, invoking Section 21(2) of the Trade Marks Act is misguided. The learned counsel for the appellant undertakes to file a digitally signed undertaking regarding this matter.

**PDF Source:** MS. PRIME CABLE INDUSTRIES v. REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS (39.pdf)

**Key Dates:**

* None mentioned on page 7

**Important Names:**

* Purushottam Singhal
* Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.
* Mr. Ghorai
* Ms. Sh...

**Other:**

None mentioned on page 7
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:1993 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021                                                                                              Page 7 of 8  
 
   
20. 
Mr. Ghorai also places reliance on Rule 17(3)2
 
 of the Trade Marks 
Rules. I am completely baffled as to how the said rule can be at of any 
application whatsoever in the present case. On its plain reading, Rule 
17(3) applies only where no address for service in India is given as 
required by Section 17(1). The address for service of the appellant, as 
given in the plaintiff’s application, was not only in India but was in 
Delhi. There was, therefore, no legitimate reason as to why, in fact, 
notice of the opposition was not served on the appellant by hand, which 
was the first method of service envisaged by Rule 14(1) of the Trade 
Marks Rules. 
21. 
In the present case, there being no proof of any service of the 
notice of opposition of dated 14th
 
 July 2006 of Respondent 2 having been 
effected on the appellant in the manner envisaged by the Trade Marks 
Rules, the invocation, by the impugned order of Section 21(2) of the 
Trade Marks Act must be held to be misguided. 
22. 
I am informed that the notice of opposition dated 14th
                                          
2 17.  
Address for service. –  
(1)  
Every applicant or opponent or any person concerned in any proceeding under the Act or rules 
shall furnish to the Registrar an address for service in India comprising of a postal address in India and a 
valid e-mail address and such address shall be treated as the address for service of such applicant or 
opponent or person: 
Provided that a trade mark agent shall also be required to furnish a mobile number registered 
in India. 
(2)  
Any written communication addressed to a person as aforesaid at an address for service in 
India given by him shall be deemed to be properly addressed. 
(3)  
Unless an address for service in India as required in sub-rule (1) is given, the Registrar shall 
be under no obligation to send any notice that may be required by the Act or the rules and no subsequent 
order or decision in the proceedings shall be called in question on the ground of any lack or non-service 
of notice.

available on the website of the Registrar of Trade Marks. Mr. Swami, 
learned Counsel for the appellant undertakes on behalf of his client to file

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the PDF:

**Case Details**

* Neutral Citation Number: 2023:DHC:1993
* Case Name: MS. Prime Cable Industries vs Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 13/2021

**Judgment**

The Court allows the appeal of the appellant, Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries.

**Order**

* The applicant should file their counterstatement to the notice of opposition within two weeks from the date of receipt of this order.
* If the applicant fails to do so, the right to file a counterstatement would stand closed.
* The Registrar may then proceed with the application in accordance with law.

**Decision and Cost**

* This appeal stands allowed with no orders as to costs.

**Date**

* March 20, 2023

Source: MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks (PDF: 39. Purushottam Singhal Proprietor MS. Prime Cable Industries v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

his counterstatement to the notice of opposition within two weeks. It is 
made clear that the appellant should do so within the said time failing 
which the right to file counterstatement would stand closed. 
 
23. 
The Registrar may thereafter proceed with the application in 
accordance with law. 
 
24. 
This appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to costs. 
 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J
